page.title: 19THE VILLAGE OF MUSBURY
page.content: Musbury village gets its name from the Iron Age hill fort which crowns the hill above the village. The Parish Church is a 15th century structure, although it has been restored. The chancel was rebuilt in 1865 and the north Aisle in 1875. There is much other Victorian work. An important feature is the Drake monument, erected in 1611. Sir Francis Drake was a distant relation of this family. There is also a Methodist Church. Musbury lies on the main road running from Seaton to Axminster.There is a garage, a post office and general stores and a pub,"The Golden Hind." A youth club meets in the new village hall. The village Primary School has 3 teachers and about 40 children. There is a road named after John Churchill, Duke of Marlborough, who is said to have been born at Ashe House.
